Established in 1922, the San Francisco Employees’ Retirement System (“SFERS”) is dedicated to securing, protecting and prudently investing pension trust (the “Trust”) assets and administering a defined benefit pension fund for eligible members of the City and County of San Francisco (the “City”), San Francisco Unified School District, City College of San Francisco, and the Superior Court for the County of San Francisco. SFERS’ Retirement Board (the “Retirement Board”) and investment team oversee the management of $25 billion in Trust assets in global public equities, fixed income and alternative investments. Our Mission The San Francisco Employees’ Retirement System is dedicated to securing, protecting and prudently investing the pension trust assets, administering mandated benefits programs, and providing promised benefits to the active and retired members of the City and County of San Francisco. While the Investment Analyst will be exposed to a variety of private markets strategies within the portfolio, it is expected that the majority of time will be allocated to private equity investment opportunities, particularly venture capital and growth. Working with the Compliance Department to devise and deploy comprehensive fair lending training, guidance and support.

Recommending improvements to internal control systems to identify and mitigate fair lending risk and assisting in the development of business line procedures, processes and product offerings and ensuring processes and controls are established to mitigate the associated regulatory risk.

Conducting monthly, quarterly, and annual aggregations of all data points required to be reported on the HMDA-LAR.
Performing validation testing of all HMDA data points to ensure that the HMDA-LAR is complete and accurate.

Summary This position is located in the Surveillance Branch of of the Division of Clearing and Risk. The program has three core functions: margin model oversight, daily risk surveillance, and supervisory stress tests.

Responsibilities As a Risk Analyst (Margin Models) in the Risk Surveillance Branch, you will: Draft documents describing margin methodology in both a high level over view and a detailed narrative. Evaluate margin models for a diverse product mix, including futures, options on futures, Credit Default Swaps, Interest Rate Swaps and other cleared over-the-counter products. Margin models evaluated will perform calculations on multi-denominated currencies. Identify risk management and analytical software needs in order to effectively perform responsibilities 1-3. Participate in all discussion on analytical software needs and the design and development of risk analysis platform. Use financial and statistical software programs such as MATLAB, R, or Python and SAS to value and stress test futures, interest rate swaps, and credit default swaps instruments and portfolios. Create personalized and group-wide stress test “what-if” analysis on identified positions, evaluates numerical and graphical results, compares potential losses to the financial condition of market participants, and evaluates portfolios for risk-reducing positions or changes in positions as a result of the stress test “what-if” calculations. Perform statistical analysis such as value at risk, expected shortfall, etc., necessary for the evaluation of margin models. Perform daily analyses of the pay/collect data received from a DCO to determine if an excess pay may present a risk to a DCO’s clearing member. Plan, coordinate, and conduct risk surveillance activities for evaluating market risk at FCMs and DCOs, conduct stress test analyses, and identify market participants that pose unusual levels of risk. Perform analyses of large trader and clearing member positions and prepare reports on information and data pertaining to the risk posed by specific registrants during times of unusual market volatility. Develop historical knowledge of the types of risk facing FCMs/DCOs. Prepare reports that set forth the findings of the analyses carried out by RSB. Participate in reviews of sufficiency of exchange-set margin levels. Perform analysis of the percentage of maintenance margin used by a change in dollar value of contracts and portfolio profit and loss on daily market moves for a selected period. Prepare on a regular basis quantitative and graphical analyses summarizing the sufficiency of exchange set margin levels, and perform analysis of the financial impact of clearing members’ mark-to-market totals across multiple exchanges. Plan and coordinate the monitoring of market news and commodity prices throughout the day and otherwise use all available information to appropriately focus special evaluations of the financial condition of market participants. Coordinate contacts with management and staff of clearinghouses, commodity exchanges, and clearing members to obtain and to share information necessary for the evaluation of market news. Maintain the Enterprise's model inventory and model documentation library.
Identify emerging model risk issues impacting the Bank, changes in industry best practice related to model development and validation, and communicate to model developers, senior management and the Model Risk Committee.

Experience with analytics software (SAS, R, SPSS, Matlab, Excel VBA, SQL), relational databases and/or 'Big Data' technologies.
